item.title: Ability Scores
item.description:
Instead of the six D&D ability scores, the Archmage system uses four primary abilities:
Strength (STR)
Measures your physical strength; both your ability to take a punch and deliver one.
Dexterity (DEX)
Measures your control over your body, your ability to jump, run, hide, and dodge
Intellegence (INT)
Measures your cognitive abilities, understanding of the world, and application of that understanding.
Presence (PRS)
Measures your mental strength, willpower, and your ability to influence and command others.
Every player and non-player character has a number for each of these ability scores, the minimum for each ability score is -3 and the maximum is 5, but player characters start with between 0 and 2 for each of these ability scores. Starting level characters have 4 points, divided as chosen. Below are real-life examples for each level of each ability score.

item.title: Actions in Combat
item.description:
Each turn in combat you gain: movement equal to your movement speed, one reaction, two actions.
Actions:

Attack
Dash
Cast a spell
Reload
Dash
Help
Stabilize or heal an ally
Anything else that takes 2-3 seconds
Movement:
By default, each character has 10m of movement per turn, and can spend it divided up between actions as they choose. For each time they dash they gain additional movement equal to their standard movement speed. Most maps are built out of either grids or hexes, where each square or hex represents 2m of distance. So to move to an adjacent tile you must spend 2m of movement, or you can spend 3m to move to a tile diagonal from you.
You can take any number of free actions at any point, but can't take the same one more than once.
Free actions:

Drop concentration
Drop an object you are holding
Speak a short phrase
Interact with an object
Drop prone
Make a social check to influence an npc
Change weapons
Cast a reactive spell (if known)
Take a free attack (if granted by an ability)
Make a knowledge check

item.title: Attacking
item.description:
Attack rolls are made by rolling and adding up , adding your Strength or Dexterity modifier depending on the weapon, and adding any additional bonuses such as skill. Then compare this to your target's armor class. If they are equal, the attack is a partial success and you deal partial damage. If your attack is greater than their armor class, the attack is a full success, and you can choose to either deal full damage, or still deal partial damage and make a special attack you have access too.
All attacks deal 1d6 damage, limited by the maximum damage specified by the weapon.

item.title: Damage & Healing
item.description:
Each player has a number of base hp equal to their level plus their brawn ability score
floor((LVL + 1) (BRN + 3) 0.25 + BRN)
When you have 0 or fewer hp, you are seriously injured and must make an injury save at the start of each of your turns round. To do so, make a strength saving throw against 7 plus the number of negative hp you have. If you fail, you lose one hp, if you fully succeed, you regain one hp, if you partially succeed, nothing changes. If you critically succeed or fail, you lose or gain two hp. While you have 0 or fewer hp you can still act as normal, but you get a penalty on all rolls equal to your amount of negative hp, and the same penalty on your movement speed in meters.
To stabilize you, an ally needs to make a medicine check or healing magic check against the same dc, 7 plus your amount of negative hp. If they roll a partial success, you become stable. As long as you are stable, the injury penalty to rolls is halved, and you only need to make an injury save every eight hours, and you get +1 on that save.

item.title: Defense and Armor
item.description: In Archmage, each character has an armor class, the same as DND. Any attack must be compared to the armor class, and must at least meet it to do damage.

item.title: Experience and Leveling Up
item.description:
Unlike in other games, players don't follow fixed classes for leveling up, and instead can choose features from a tree-like progression chart. Players will be rewarded with experience points after completing adventures (on average one point per 2-3 hours of adventure). Players in a party usually gain xp points together, at the same rate. The next time your character has an opportunity to spend time training or learning, you can spend these experience points, to unlock new abilities. These xp points are also consumed by some abilities, such as spells to revive the dead or travel between planes, and the creation of very powerful magic items.
Sometimes you will also have special opportunities to spend xp, for instance you might encounter a scroll explaining a spell or ability, or an npc willing to teach you a special technique. If you don't have xp available at the time you can un-learn an ability to regain the xp points spent on it, but once you do so you can never re-learn it.
The feature tree is also divided into levels, these simply limit you from heading too far down any particular skill tree early on, and force you to diversify your abilities. Each level is unlocked after you get a number of experience points equal to that level, not including ones gained for previous levels. Reaching a new level doesn't automatically unlock any new abilities, but it does grant you access to new features which you can unlock using experience points.

item.title: Introduction
item.description:
Archmage is designed to allow for a more intuitive RPG system that is less restrained by rules and more free for storytelling by the DM and players. This more light-weight approach to rules relies on the expectation that the DM will set fair DCs and give fair modifiers, and that the players will not try to exploit cracks in the rules.
Despite it's name, the Archmage system is quite customizable, and can be made to fit any setting. The easiest way to modify it, is by choosing to make some paths unavailable to players. You could, for instance, make all magical paths unavailable in a setting without magic, or make the path of the gunslinger unavailable in medival settings. Alternatively, you could start with some certain paths being unavailable to players, but grant them access to all or part of it as a rewards, when they gain access to rare technology or arcana in the game.
While it still has traditional combat, it is intended to host stories with more focus on roleplay and exploration, and it's rules are built accordingly.
-- add note about the fashion of discreetness
Problems in d&d solved by this game:

Much less math related to attacks, damage, and hp
Smooth progression, without power level jumps or long stretches of no new abilities
More freedom in character creation than with fixed classes
More freedom with storytelling, without sacrificing combat ability, including balanced weapons and spells
Balance of situational and general features
More freedom in spellcasting
More intuitive hp and damage system

item.title: Schools of Magic
item.description:
Sanctifism (Presence Only)
Sanctifism practitioners draw upon their inner strength and connection to divine energies to heal wounds, cure ailments, and restore vitality to themselves and others. Their magic radiates with a holy light, capable of purifying darkness and bringing hope to those in need.
Artifice (Intellegence Only)
Artificers are masters of craftsmanship and invention, utilizing their keen Intellegence to repair broken objects, create intricate constructs, and imbue mundane items with magical properties. Their magic is rooted in the principles of engineering and arcane knowledge, allowing them to shape raw materials into wondrous creations.
Necromancy
Practitioners of necromancy wield the dark powers of death and decay, commanding the forces of the undead and draining the life force of their enemies. With mastery over both physical and mental energies, necromancers can raise armies of the dead and harness forbidden knowledge from beyond the grave.
Divination
Diviners possess the gift of foresight and insight, using their powers to peer into the past, present, and future. Through the manipulation of time and space, diviners can unravel mysteries, uncover hidden truths, and peer into the depths of the unknown with unparalleled clarity.
Floramancy
Floramancers commune with the natural world, channeling the primal energies of plants and flora to manipulate their growth, heal wounds, and harness the power of nature itself. Their magic is intertwined with the cycle of life and death, allowing them to shape the environment to their will and nurture life wherever they go.
Psionics
Psions are wielders of the mind, capable of bending reality to their will through sheer mental prowess. With telekinetic abilities, mind control, and telepathy at their disposal, psions can influence the thoughts and actions of others, reshape the environment, and transcend the limitations of the physical world.
Evocation
Illusion
Illusionists are masters of deception and trickery, capable of creating lifelike illusions and manipulating the perceptions of others. Their magic can cloak their allies in shadows, conjure phantom images, and sow confusion among their enemies, making them formidable foes on the battlefield and adept infiltrators in the world of espionage.

item.title: Skills & Checks
item.description:
Skills
All your skills are stored in lists, each one under the associated ability score. You will choose skills as you creature your character, and might gain more as your character gains experience. Each skill is associated with a ability score, this is the ability score it is usually used with, but not always.
The DM might also impose an extra modifier for situational reasons, making something easier with a positive modifier or harder with a negative modifier.
Each check has a difficulty class (DC) needed for success. Higher DCs indicate more challenging tasks. Failure occurs if your roll is less than the DC, with the severity of failure determined by the difference between your roll and the DC. Rolling equal to the DC results in a partial success, while exceeding the DC grants a full success.
Here is a guide for determining task DCs, with corresponding D&D DCs for comparison:

DC 5 - Very Easy (D&D 5)
DC 7 - Easy (D&D 10)
DC 9 - Simple (D&D 12)
DC 11 - Moderate (D&D 15)
DC 13 - Challenging (D&D 18)
DC 14 - Difficult (D&D 20)
DC 15 - Very Difficult (D&D 22)
DC 17 - Extremely Difficult (D&D 25)
DC 18 - Near Impossible (D&D 28)
DC 19 - Godlike (D&D 30)
Additionally, if you roll a Natural 12, you automatically fully succeed regardless of the task's difficulty. Conversely, rolling a Natural 1 results in automatic failure. If you roll a natural 12 on a check that would require someone else to make a save, instead they fail automatically.

item.title: Spellcasting
item.description:
In order to cast a spell, you will need:

Spellcasting unlocked
You must have the first level of magical path
A source of magical knowledge
This can be a library of the arcane, a teacher with arcane experience, a beginners magic book, ancient text, your own studies, or anything else.
A magical focus.
This can be a wand, a staff, a magic hat, an amulet, a magical weapon, or anything else that has been attuned to resonate magic.
Most magical foci grant a bonus to a certain school of magic.
You can cast spells without a focus, but you get -1 on your rolls.
As long as you do not have a negative penalty, you automatically succeed at casting spells that are at most half of the maximum level you have unlocked in any path.

item.title: Weapons
item.description:
In Archmage, all melee weapons are divided into three categories:
Light
Light weapons always use your Dexterity score, you can fight with a light weapon in either hand. Examples include daggers, shortswords, and light hammers.
Medium
Medium weapons can use your Dexterity score or Strength score, you can hold one medium and one small weapon but not two medium weapons. Examples include longswords, spears, light clubs, staffs
Heavy
Heavy weapons use only your Strength score and
Light weapons are considered tiny, medium and heavy weapons are considered small.
